articles.headline: A Toolkit for Women Seeking a Raise
articles.snippet: One cause of the pay gap between men and women may be how women approach negotiations, researchers say.
articles.abstract: One cause of the pay gap between men and women may be how women approach negotiations, researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even now, when women represent half the work force, they’re still paid considerably less than men — and part of that pay gap may be a result of what happens at the salary negotiation table.

articles.headline: Kansas Mutual Fund Is Linked to Market’s Plunge
articles.snippet: Futures trades by Waddell & Reed, a mutual fund based in Kansas, have been linked to the May 6 “flash crash” of the Dow.
articles.abstract: Futures trades by Waddell & Reed, a mutual fund based in Kansas, have been linked to the May 6 “flash crash” of the Dow.
articles.lead_paragraph: The flash crash on May 6 that transfixed investors — and has been the source of finger-pointing ever since — may not have originated in the canyons of Wall Street or a hedge fund manager’s European lair.

articles.headline: Debit Fee Cut Is a Rare Loss for Big Banks
articles.snippet: An amendment to the Senate’s financial legislation that imposes price controls is a victory for retailers after years of fighting banking industry lobbyists. Consumers also could save money.
articles.abstract: An amendment to the Senate’s financial legislation that imposes price controls is a victory for retailers after years of fighting banking industry lobbyists. Consumers also could save money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Retailers have begged Congress for years, in vain, to limit the fees they must pay to banks when customers swipe credit or debit cards. Bills never reached a vote. Amendments were left on the table. The Senate did not even grant the courtesy of a committee hearing.

articles.headline: Google Says It Collected Private Data by Mistake
articles.snippet: The company said a programming error resulted in the collecting of snippets of data that happened to be transmitted over nonpassword protected Wi-Fi networks that the Google camera cars were passing.
articles.abstract: The company said a programming error resulted in the collecting of snippets of data that happened to be transmitted over nonpassword protected Wi-Fi networks that the Google camera cars were passing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that for more than three years it had inadvertently collected snippets of private information that people send over unencrypted wireless networks.

articles.headline: In Search of Adorable, as Hello Kitty Gets Closer to Goodbye
articles.snippet: As the adorable white cat’s popularity and profits wane, Sanrio looks for new characters with mixed results.
articles.abstract: As the adorable white cat’s popularity and profits wane, Sanrio looks for new characters with mixed results.

articles.headline: Study Pokes Holes in Air Bag Standards
articles.snippet: A study suggests that new designs may place belted drivers at a greater risk than the air bags they replaced.
articles.abstract: A study suggests that new designs may place belted drivers at a greater risk than the air bags they replaced.
articles.lead_paragraph: New research into front air bags in automobiles is raising troubling questions about their effectiveness for drivers wearing seat belts.

articles.headline: In South Africa, an Unlikely Leader on AIDS
articles.snippet: President Jacob Zuma has been criticized for his personal behavior, but his anti-AIDS program is drawing praise.
articles.abstract: President Jacob Zuma has been criticized for his personal behavior, but his anti-AIDS program is drawing praise.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — In a nation ravaged by AIDS, a disease still hidden in shadows of stigma and shame, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa has begun to engage in an extraordinarily open conversation about sex, AIDS and H.I.V. prevention, one ignited in part by his own recent admission that he had unprotected sex during an extramarital affair.

articles.headline: G.I.’s Find Bullets Still Flying at Outpost in Iraq
articles.snippet: Military commanders worry that an area in the north offers a glimpse of a post-American Sunni insurgency.
articles.abstract: Military commanders worry that an area in the north offers a glimpse of a post-American Sunni insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASH SHURA, Iraq — Technically, American soldiers have stopped fighting in Iraq. But they can fire back when attacked, which happens frequently in this village of wheat and barley farmers, as well as an uncomfortable number of Baathist insurgents.

articles.headline: Thailand’s King Sees His Influence Fading
articles.snippet: A battle over Thailand’s future is raging, but the one man who has been able to resolve such conflicts in the past has been notably silent: King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
articles.abstract: A battle over Thailand’s future is raging, but the one man who has been able to resolve such conflicts in the past has been notably silent: King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A battle over Thailand’s future is raging, but the one man who has been able to resolve such intractable conflicts in the past has been notably silent: King Bhumibol Adulyadej, long a unifying father figure for his nation.
articles.byline: By Seth Mydans and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Building Is Booming in a City of Empty Houses
articles.snippet: Cities like Las Vegas, where thousands of new houses sit empty, are building what they do not need.
articles.abstract: Cities like Las Vegas, where thousands of new houses sit empty, are building what they do not need.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In a plastic tent under a glorious desert sky, Richard Lee preached the gospel of the second chance.

articles.headline: Is Ben Bernanke Having Fun Yet?
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Reserve hasn’t had much time to reflect on whether history’s verdict on his extraordinary actions of recent years will be harsh or forgiving.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve hasn’t had much time to reflect on whether history’s verdict on his extraordinary actions of recent years will be harsh or forgiving.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: A Scrappy Insurer Wrestles With Reform
articles.snippet: WellPoint has bet heavily on selling health insurance to individuals and small businesses, but it must now deal with the limits of the new health care law.
articles.abstract: WellPoint has bet heavily on selling health insurance to individuals and small businesses, but it must now deal with the limits of the new health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANGELA F. BRALY never hesitates to speak up for her company. In the last several months, Ms. Braly, the chief executive of WellPoint, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, has tangled with state regulators, Congress and the Obama administration over concerns that it charges customers too much or engages in questionable tactics to avoid paying claims.

articles.headline: A Credit Union That Played With Fire
articles.snippet: A Florida institution bellyflopped into a pool of exotic securities just as mortgage mania was faltering.
articles.abstract: A Florida institution bellyflopped into a pool of exotic securities just as mortgage mania was faltering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Wall Street is accused — as it has been so often these days — of selling risky products to unwitting customers, it usually argues that investors in such exotic stuff are sophisticated adults capable of assessing any hidden dangers.

articles.headline: Giant Plumes of Oil Forming Under the Gulf
articles.snippet: The discovery of the plumes, one as large as 10 miles long, is evidence that the leak could be substantially worse than estimates.
articles.abstract: The discovery of the plumes, one as large as 10 miles long, is evidence that the leak could be substantially worse than estimates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scientists are finding enormous oil plumes in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico, including one as large as 10 miles long, 3 miles wide and 300 feet thick in spots. The discovery is fresh evidence that the leak from the broken undersea well could be substantially worse than estimates that the government and BP have given.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Still Using Private Spy Ring, Despite Doubts
articles.snippet: Despite military concerns, a contractor network of spies is still operating and has become an important source of intelligence in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Despite military concerns, a contractor network of spies is still operating and has become an important source of intelligence in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top military officials have continued to rely on a secret network of private spies who have produced hundreds of reports from deep inside Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to American officials and businessmen, despite concerns among some in the military about the legality of the operation.

articles.headline: BP Reports Some Success in Capturing Leaking Oil
articles.snippet: Engineers achieved some success by using a mile-long pipe to capture some of the oil flow and to divert it to a drill ship on the surface, company officials said.
articles.abstract: Engineers achieved some success by using a mile-long pipe to capture some of the oil flow and to divert it to a drill ship on the surface, company officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After more than three weeks of efforts to stop a gushing oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico, BP engineers achieved some success on Sunday when they used a milelong pipe to capture some of the oil and divert it to a drill ship on the surface some 5,000 feet above the wellhead, company officials said.

articles.headline: Taylor Momsen Did Not Write This Headline
articles.snippet: Once, headlines were meant to be clever or catchy or evocative. Now they are there to get search engines to notice.
articles.abstract: Once, headlines were meant to be clever or catchy or evocative. Now they are there to get search engines to notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don’t know who Taylor Momsen is? Neither do I, beyond that she is the mean one on “Gossip Girl.” But Facebook knows her well, Twitter loves her, and she and Google have been hooking up, like, forever.

articles.headline: Fans of Gourmet Magazine Accept No Stand-Ins
articles.snippet: In the fight over Gourmet magazine’s former readers, it’s the mass-market food magazines that seem to be thriving.
articles.abstract: In the fight over Gourmet magazine’s former readers, it’s the mass-market food magazines that seem to be thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Loren Shlaes, a pediatric occupational therapist in Manhattan, is the kind of amateur cook who bakes cakes for her friends’ weddings and makes her own spaetzle. She’s an avid reader of food magazines, and, over the years, has subscribed to Cook’s Country, Cook’s Illustrated, Saveur, Everyday Food and, beginning in the early 1990s, Gourmet.

articles.headline: TV Networks Go on a Pilot Buying Spree
articles.snippet: The television networks have all ramped up their development efforts this season, all searching for badly needed hits.
articles.abstract: The television networks have all ramped up their development efforts this season, all searching for badly needed hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a season of disappointing ad revenue, the further loss of viewers (and prestige) to cable networks, the end of popular series like “Lost” and “24” and the Jay Leno disaster at NBC, the broadcast networks are going back to an expensive drawing board.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Taliban Hold Sway in Area Taken by U.S., Farmers Say
articles.snippet: The farmers’ departure is an indication that Taliban fighters have found a way to resume their insurgency in Marja.
articles.abstract: The farmers’ departure is an indication that Taliban fighters have found a way to resume their insurgency in Marja.
articles.lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — Farmers from the district of Marja, which since February has been the focus of the largest American-led military operation in Afghanistan, are fleeing the area, saying that the Taliban are terrorizing the population and that American troops cannot protect the civilians.

articles.headline: Fears Intensify That Euro Crisis Could Snowball
articles.snippet: Investors continued to abandon the currency on Monday, as concerns rose that banks would cut back on loans, crimping growth.
articles.abstract: Investors continued to abandon the currency on Monday, as concerns rose that banks would cut back on loans, crimping growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a brief respite following the announcement last week of a nearly $1 trillion bailout plan for Europe, fear in the financial markets is building again, this time over worries that the Continent’s biggest banks face strains that will hobble European economies.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Speedy New Traders Make Waves Far From Wall St.
articles.snippet: After a brief 1,000-point plunge in the stock market on May 6, high-frequency traders are drawing new scrutiny.
articles.abstract: After a brief 1,000-point plunge in the stock market on May 6, high-frequency traders are drawing new scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: RED BANK, N.J. — Above the Restoration Hardware in this Jersey Shore town, not far from the Navesink River, lurks a Wall Street giant.

articles.headline: In Three Primaries, Measures of Voter Discontent
articles.snippet: Tuesday’s primaries in Kentucky, Pennsylvania and Arkansas will help frame the debate for the midterms.
articles.abstract: Tuesday’s primaries in Kentucky, Pennsylvania and Arkansas will help frame the debate for the midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Ky. — Rand Paul grabbed a microphone, climbed onto a short brick wall and told a gathering crowd of supporters to brace for an Election Day uprising on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Euro Zone Likes a Weaker Currency, Up to a Point
articles.snippet: The volatility of the euro is unnerving managers at factories across the Continent, and more than anything at this point, Europe longs for stability.
articles.abstract: The volatility of the euro is unnerving managers at factories across the Continent, and more than anything at this point, Europe longs for stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In Europe, businesses are generally giddy to see the euro fall and exports rise. But the currency’s plunge in recent days is starting to make the Continent nervous.

articles.headline: At YouTube, Adolescence Begins at 5
articles.snippet: Chad Hurley, YouTube’s chief executive, says that professional video is drawing ever larger and more engaged audiences to the Google subsidiary, a sign that the site is growing up.
articles.abstract: Chad Hurley, YouTube’s chief executive, says that professional video is drawing ever larger and more engaged audiences to the Google subsidiary, a sign that the site is growing up.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Early this year, the most popular YouTube video of all time — a 2007 clip of a British toddler gleefully biting the finger of his older brother — was supplanted by a brash newcomer.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Skeptical on Iranian Deal for Nuclear Fuel
articles.snippet: Monday’s agreement, negotiated by Brazil and Turkey, could undermine efforts in the U.N. to impose new sanctions on Iran.
articles.abstract: Monday’s agreement, negotiated by Brazil and Turkey, could undermine efforts in the U.N. to impose new sanctions on Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States, Europe and Russia responded with extreme skepticism to Iran’s announcement on Monday that it had reached an agreement to ship roughly half of its nuclear fuel to Turkey, saying they would continue to press for new sanctions against Tehran.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: G.M. Posts Profit as Sales Rise 40 Percent
articles.snippet: The automaker said that it earned $865 million in the first quarter and that it would increase production.
articles.abstract: The automaker said that it earned $865 million in the first quarter and that it would increase production.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors said Monday that it earned its first quarterly profit since 2007 after last year’s government-sponsored bankruptcy allowed the carmaker to wipe away many of its longstanding obligations.
